title: Utility of Amyloid Beta-peptide 1-40 Measurement in the Diagnosis of Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: The combined measurement of Ab42 and tau protein (total and phosphorylated) in the spinal fluid has been shown to be promising in the diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease (AD), and has justified its inclusion new diagnostic criteria. However, it can sometimes yield discordant results that are not discriminant (isolated variation in Ab42 or P-181 Tau). To answer this challenge, a new marker has been developed in recent years, namely amyloid beta-peptide 1-40 (Aβ40). This marker reflects the patient's total amyloid deposits and is used to calculate the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio. This ratio measures the relative variation of Aβ42 as compared to the total amyloid burden. Literature data on this topic are sparse and to date, no report has been published evaluating the utility of this marker in the diagnostic strategy for AD.
explanation_target: Reason: The description is a diagnostic/biomarker study evaluating cerebrospinal fluid amyloid beta‑peptide 1‑40 (Aβ40) and the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio to improve interpretation of existing CSF markers (Aβ42, total tau, p‑tau). This is an observational/diagnostic test evaluation, not an interventional drug trial — no therapeutic agent, mechanism of action, or symptom/cognition endpoint is described. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Act: I searched the literature to confirm the role of CSF Aβ40 and the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio in AD diagnosis. Multiple studies and reviews show that measuring Aβ40 (or the Aβ42/Aβ40 ratio) improves diagnostic accuracy and reduces discordant CSF results compared with Aβ42 alone (examples: validation of Aβ40 assays and improved AUC/concordance with amyloid PET; large-sample analyses showing added value of Aβ40 or the ratio). These references support that the trial description is diagnostic/biomarker work rather than a drug trial. citeturn0search0turn0search1turn0search2turn0search4turn0search6

Reflect: Classification as 'N/A' (not applicable to the four therapeutic categories) aligns with the study aim — evaluating a biomarker (Aβ40 / Aβ42:Aβ40 ratio) to improve diagnostic interpretation. No drug name, biologic, small molecule, cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric intervention is present. Therefore 'N/A' is the correct category.
